Definition: Paget's disease is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and deformed bones.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve genetic factors and viral infections.
Symptoms: Bone pain, deformities, and fractures.
Treatment: Medications to regulate bone remodeling and pain management.

Definition: Pancreatic cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the tissues of the pancreas.
Causes: Smoking, obesity, and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, blood tests, and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are rare tumors that arise from the hormone-producing cells of the pancreas.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic syndromes.
Symptoms: Varies widely; may include hormonal symptoms and abdominal pain.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, blood tests, and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, targeted therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas that can be acute or chronic.
Causes: Gallstones, chronic and excessive alcohol consumption, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, imaging studies, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Hospitalization, pain management, and dietary changes.

Definition: Panic disorder is an anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks.
Causes: Genetic factors, brain chemistry, and environmental stressors.
Symptoms: Rapid heartbeat, sweating, trembling, and feelings of impending doom.
Treatment: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), medications, and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Paraganglioma is a rare tumor that arises from paraganglia, which are clusters of neuroendocrine cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations and hereditary syndromes.
Symptoms: Headaches, sweating, and high blood pressure.
Treatment: Surgery and management of symptoms.

condition: Paranasal Sinus and Nasal Cavity Cancer

Definition: Cancer that occurs in the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity.
Causes: Exposure to certain chemicals, smoking, and viral infections.
Symptoms: Nasal obstruction, facial pain, and bleeding.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: A parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can cause hyperparathyroidism.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: High calcium levels, fatigue, and kidney stones.
Treatment: Surgery to remove the adenoma and management of calcium levels.

Definition: Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that affects movement.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Tremors, stiffness, and bradykinesia (slowness of movement).
Treatment: Medications, physical therapy, and in some cases, surgery.

Definition: Patent foramen ovale is a small opening between the right and left atria of the heart that fails to close after birth.
Causes: Congenital heart defect.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; may be associated with stroke or migraine.
Treatment: Monitoring, medications, and closure procedures if symptomatic.

Definition: A PCL injury is a sprain or tear of the posterior cruciate ligament in the knee.
Causes: Direct impact to the knee or sudden twisting motions.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and instability in the knee.
Treatment: Rest, ice, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Pectus carinatum is a chest wall deformity characterized by a protrusion of the sternum.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Visible chest deformity and possible respiratory issues.
Treatment: Bracing and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: Pectus excavatum is a chest wall deformity characterized by a sunken sternum.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Visible chest deformity and possible respiratory issues.
Treatment: Bracing and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: Pelvic floor disorders are conditions that affect the muscles and tissues supporting the pelvic organs.
Causes: Childbirth, aging, and obesity.
Symptoms: Pelvic pain, urinary incontinence, and bowel dysfunction.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and surgery.

Definition: Penile cancer is a rare type of cancer that occurs on the skin or in the tissues of the penis.
Causes: Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and smoking.
Symptoms: Lump or growth on the penis, changes in skin color, and discharge.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Peptic ulcer disease is a condition where open sores develop on the lining of the stomach or the first part of the small intestine.
Causes: Helicobacter pylori infection and long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, bloating, and indigestion.
Treatment: Medications to reduce stomach acid and antibiotics for H. pylori.

Definition: Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs.
Treatment: Medications to manage heart failure and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Peripheral artery disease is a circulatory condition in which narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs.
Causes: Atherosclerosis, smoking, and diabetes.
Symptoms: Leg pain when walking, numbness, and weakness.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Peripheral neuropathy is a condition resulting from damage to the peripheral nerves, causing weakness, numbness, and pain.
Causes: Diabetes, infections, and exposure to toxins.
Symptoms: Numbness, tingling, and pain in the hands and feet.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and nerve conduction studies.
Treatment: Medications for pain relief and management of underlying conditions.

Definition: Pernicious anemia is a type of anemia caused by the inability to absorb vitamin B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factor.
Causes: Autoimmune destruction of gastric cells and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, and neurological symptoms.
Treatment: Vitamin B12 injections and dietary changes.

Definition: Peyronie's disease is a condition characterized by the development of fibrous scar tissue in the penis, causing curved, painful erections.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve trauma or genetic factors.
Symptoms: Curvature of the penis, pain, and erectile dysfunction.
Treatment: Medications, injections, and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal gland that produces excess catecholamines, leading to high blood pressure.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic syndromes.
Symptoms: High blood pressure, headaches, sweating, and palpitations.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, urine tests, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Surgery and management of blood pressure.

Definition: Pick's disease is a rare form of frontotemporal dementia characterized by progressive changes in personality and behavior.
Causes: Genetic mutations and abnormal protein deposits in the brain.
Symptoms: Personality changes, language difficulties, and social withdrawal.
Treatment: Supportive care and management of symptoms.

Definition: A pituitary tumor is an abnormal growth in the pituitary gland, which can affect hormone production.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Headaches, vision changes, and hormonal imbalances.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and hormone level tests.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and medications.

Definition: Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta attaches too deeply into the uterine wall.
Causes: Previous cesarean sections and uterine surgery.
Symptoms: Abnormal bleeding during pregnancy and complications during delivery.
Treatment: Careful monitoring and possible surgical intervention.

Definition: Plantar fasciitis is an inflammation of the plantar fascia, the tissue that runs along the bottom of the foot.
Causes: Overuse, improper footwear, and obesity.
Symptoms: Heel pain, especially with the first steps in the morning.
Treatment: Rest, ice, stretching exercises, and orthotics.

Definition: Plastic bronchitis is a rare condition characterized by the formation of thick, rubbery casts in the airways.
Causes: Often associated with underlying lung diseases or heart failure.
Symptoms: Coughing up casts, difficulty breathing, and wheezing.
Treatment: Management of underlying conditions and airway clearance techniques.

Definition: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of excess fluid between the layers of the pleura outside the lungs.
Causes: Heart failure, pneumonia, and malignancies.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough.
Treatment: Draining the fluid and treating the underlying cause.

Definition: Pleurisy is inflammation of the pleura, the membrane surrounding the lungs.
Causes: Infections, autoimmune diseases, and lung cancer.
Symptoms: Sharp chest pain that worsens with breathing or coughing.
Treatment: Pain management and treatment of the underlying cause.

Definition: Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavity.
Causes: Trauma, rupture of the esophagus, and excessive coughing.
Symptoms: Chest pain, difficulty breathing, and neck swelling.
Treatment: Observation and management of underlying causes.

Definition: Pneumothorax is a condition where air leaks into the space between the lung and chest wall, causing the lung to collapse.
Causes: Trauma, lung disease, and spontaneous rupture of air blisters.
Symptoms: Sudden chest pain and shortness of breath.
Treatment: Observation, needle decompression, or chest tube insertion.

Definition: Polycystic ovary syndrome is a hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Irregular periods, excess hair growth, and acne.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, and management of symptoms.

Definition: Polyposis syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of multiple polyps in the gastrointestinal tract.
Causes: Genetic mutations and hereditary factors.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic until complications arise; may include gastrointestinal bleeding.
Treatment: Regular surveillance and surgical removal of polyps.

Definition: Pregnancy is the condition of carrying a developing embryo or fetus within the female body.
Causes: Fertilization of an egg by sperm.
Symptoms: Missed periods, nausea, and breast tenderness.
Treatment: Prenatal care and management of pregnancy-related conditions.

Definition: Primary biliary cirrhosis is a chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in the liver.
Causes: Autoimmune response against the bile ducts.
Symptoms: Fatigue, itching, and jaundice.
Treatment: Medications to manage symptoms and liver transplant in severe cases.

Definition: Primary CNS lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the central nervous system.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve immunosuppression.
Symptoms: Headaches, seizures, and neurological deficits.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Progressive supranuclear palsy is a rare brain disorder that causes serious problems with walking, balance, and eye movements.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve abnormal protein accumulation in the brain.
Symptoms: Balance problems, difficulty with eye movements, and cognitive decline.
Treatment: Supportive care and management of symptoms.

Definition: Prolactinoma is a benign tumor of the pituitary gland that produces excess prolactin.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Irregular menstrual periods, infertility, and galactorrhea (milk production).
Treatment: Medications to lower prolactin levels and surgery in some cases.

Definition: Prostate cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the prostate gland.
Causes: Age, family history, and certain genetic mutations.
Symptoms: Difficulty urinating, blood in urine, and pelvic pain.
Diagnosis: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test, imaging studies, and biopsy.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, and active surveillance.

Definition: Protein-losing enteropathy is a condition characterized by excessive loss of protein from the gastrointestinal tract.
Causes: Celiac disease, Crohn's disease, and infections.
Symptoms: Edema, diarrhea, and weight loss.
Diagnosis: Stool tests, blood tests, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Management of underlying conditions and dietary changes.

Definition: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes rapid skin cell production, leading to scaling and inflammation.
Causes: Genetic factors and immune system dysfunction.
Symptoms: Red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales.
Treatment: Topical treatments, phototherapy, and systemic medications.

Definition: Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis.
Causes: Genetic factors and immune system dysfunction.
Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, often accompanied by skin lesions.
Treatment: Medications to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms.

Definition: Psychosis is a mental health condition characterized by a disconnection from reality.
Causes: Mental illnesses, substance abuse, and medical conditions.
Symptoms: Hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking.
Treatment: Medications, therapy, and support services.

Definition: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a rare lung disease characterized by the accumulation of proteinaceous material in the alveoli.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve autoimmune factors.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue.
Treatment: Whole lung lavage and management of symptoms.

Definition: Pulmonary edema is a condition characterized by excess fluid in the lungs.
Causes: Heart failure, pneumonia, and exposure to toxins.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, wheezing, and coughing up pink, frothy sputum.
Treatment: Oxygen therapy, medications, and management of underlying causes.

Definition: Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots.
Causes: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and prolonged immobility.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chest pain, and coughing up blood.
Treatment: Anticoagulants, thrombolytics, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Pulmonary hypertension is high blood pressure in the blood vessels that supply the lungs.
Causes: Heart disease, lung disease, and blood clots.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and right heart catheterization.
Treatment: Medications, oxygen therapy, and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Pulmonary valve stenosis is a heart defect characterized by narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which obstructs blood flow from the heart to the lungs.
Causes: Congenital heart defect and rheumatic fever.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and heart murmur.
Treatment: Monitoring, balloon valvuloplasty, and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: Pulmonary veno occlusive disease is a rare form of pulmonary hypertension caused by obstruction of the pulmonary veins.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies and right heart catheterization.
Treatment: Management of symptoms and sometimes lung transplantation.

Definition: Pulsatile tinnitus is a type of tinnitus where the person hears a rhythmic sound that often matches their heartbeat.
Causes: Blood vessel disorders, high blood pressure, and ear abnormalities.
Symptoms: Hearing a pulsing sound in the ears.
Treatment: Management of underlying conditions and sound therapy.
